title: 109_hr5933
content: The "Business Travel Facilitation Act of 2006" may be cited as the Business Travel Facilitation Act. This Act pertains to business facilitation visitors. Section 214 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include business facilitation visitors, defined as aliens visiting the US temporarily for business purposes such as providing services or receiving management training. Aliens visiting the US temporarily for business purposes must meet certain conditions, including being a national of a country certified by the Secretary of Homeland Security to combat visa fraud. Aliens visiting the US for business must meet conditions, including being from a country certified by the Secretary of Homeland Security to combat visa fraud. The consular officer must verify the conditions for visa application. Alien applies for a visa under section 101(a)(15)(B) based on evidence provided, meeting conditions for provision of services paid by employer and possessing qualifications. The alien's employer will pay for expenses related to providing services, and the alien must be qualified with expert knowledge and necessary licenses. The alien must have all necessary licenses and authorizations to provide services in the United States. If receiving management or technical training, the alien must be an employee of a firm affiliated with a US entity. The alien must be an employee of a firm affiliated with a US entity through ownership, joint venture, or business transactions for training related to such activities. The alien must be an employee of a firm affiliated with a US entity through ownership, joint venture, or business transactions for training related to such activities. The training must be related to purchasing or selling goods or services to the US entity, with all expenses covered by the employer. The alien seeking to provide management training must have at least 5 years of relevant experience. The alien's employer must pay for the training. The alien seeking management training needs 5 years of relevant experience and detailed knowledge of the employer's business operations. The alien must hold a management level position within the employer within 1 year of completing the training. The period of authorized admission for an alien admitted as a business facilitation visitor providing professional services shall not exceed 1 year, with a possible 6-month extension granted by the Secretary of Homeland Security based on evidence provided. The Secretary of Homeland Security may grant a single 6-month extension to an alien providing professional services if there is an unforeseen delay in completing the services and replacing the alien would further delay the contract fulfillment. The period of authorized admission for a business facilitation visitor providing or receiving management or technical training may not exceed 1 year. An alien admitted as a business facilitation visitor is not eligible for a change of nonimmigrant status or adjustment to immigrant status during their stay in the United States. The Secretary of Homeland Security may prohibit nationals from admission as business facilitation visitors if there is a pattern of fraud. The Secretary of Homeland Security may prohibit nationals from admission to the United States as business facilitation visitors if there is a pattern of fraud involving visa applications or immigration matters. A qualifying services contract is defined as a contract between a foreign provider of professional services and a United States entity, outlining the time period, duties, and provisions for the alien's presence in the United States. The qualifying services contract specifies the time period, duties, and provisions for the alien's presence in the United States, including remuneration, expenses, and working conditions comparable to those of similarly situated providers. The alien must have working conditions comparable to those of similar providers of professional services, possess necessary credentials, and comply with the terms of the contract. The foreign provider must have authorizations to offer services in the United States and ensure the alien's compliance with admission terms and return to their home country.
